lesson.name: Lesson 7.4: Comparing Quadratic and Exponential Functions

page.title: 7.4.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will investigate how quantities that grow quadratically compare to those that grow exponentially. You will use different mathematical models to show the relationship between the functions to determine which one grows faster.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Explain using graphs, tables, or calculations how exponential functions eventually grow faster than quadratic functions.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 7.4.1: Comparing Expressions
  • 7.4.2: Exploring Linear, Exponential, and Quadratic Growth
    • 7.4.2: Self Check
    • 7.4.2: Additional Resources
  • 7.4.3: Comparing Exponential and Quadratic Functions
    • 7.4.3: Self Check
    • 7.4.3: Additional Resources
  • 7.4.4: Comparing Exponential and Quadratic Expressions

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 7.4.5: Practice
  • 7.4.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 7.4.1: Comparing Expressions
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

List these quantities in order, from least to greatest, without evaluating each expression. Be prepared to explain your reasoning.

  1. \(2^{10}\)
  2. \(10^2\)
  3. \(2^9\)
  4. \(9^2\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

The correct order is \(9^2\), \(10^2\), \(2^9\), \(2^{10}\). This would be 18, 100, 512, 1024.

page.title: 7.4.2: Exploring Linear, Exponential, and Quadratic Growth
page.contents:
In this activity, you will compare two different patterns. In each pattern, the number of small squares is a function of the step number, \(n\).

  • In Pattern A, the length and width of the rectangle grow by 1 small square from each step to the next.

Pattern A


  1. Write an equation to represent the number of small squares at Step \(n\) in Pattern A.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(f(n)=n^2\)

  1. Is the function in Pattern A linear, quadratic, or exponential?

Correct! It is quadratic.

Incorrect. The correct answer is quadratic.

  1. Complete the table for Pattern A.
\(n\), step number \(f(n)\), number of small squares
\(0\)  
\(1\)  
\(2\)  
\(3\)  
\(4\)  
\(5\)  
\(6\)  
\(7\)  
\(8\)  

Write down your answers, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answers:

\(n\), step number

\(f(n)\), number of small squares
\(0\) \(0\)
\(1\) \(1\)
\(2\) \(4\)
\(3\) \(9\)
\(4\) \(16\)
\(5\) \(25\)
\(6\) \(36\)
\(7\) \(49\)
\(8\) \(64\)
  1. In Pattern B, the number of small squares doubles from each step to the next.

Pattern B


  1. Write an equation to represent the number of small squares at Step \(n\) in Pattern B.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(g(n)=2^n\)

  1. Is the function in Pattern B linear, quadratic, or exponential?

Correct! It is exponential.

Incorrect. The correct answer is exponential.

  1. Complete the table for Pattern B.
\(n\), step number \(g(n)\), number of small squares
\(0\)  
\(1\)  
\(2\)  
\(3\)  
\(4\)  
\(5\)  
\(6\)  
\(7\)  
\(8\)  

Write down your answers, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answers:

\(n\), step number \(g(n)\), number of small squares
\(0\) \(1\)
\(1\) \(2\)
\(2\) \(4\)
\(3\) \(8\)
\(4\) \(16\)
\(5\) \(32\)
\(6\) \(64\)
\(7\) \(128\)
\(8\) \(256\)

  1. How would the two patterns compare if they continue to grow? Make one to two observations.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The number of small squares in Pattern B grows much more quickly than the number of squares in Pattern A once \(n\) is greater than \(5\). The patterns have the same number of squares when \(n=2\) and when \(n=4\).

page.title: 7.4.2: Self Check
page.contents: Which of the following functions has a constant growth factor?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The slope of this linear function is \(4\), creating a common difference of \(4\). The answer is \(f(x)=4^x\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Quadratic functions do not have a constant growth factor like exponential functions. The answer is \(f(x)=4^x\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: This exponential function has a growth factor of \(4\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This linear function has a \(y\)-intercept of \(4\) but a slope or common difference of \(1\). The answer is \(f(x)=4^x\).

page.title: 7.4.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Determining Growth Factors

Is the pattern below represented by a function that is linear, exponential, or quadratic?

Step 1
Draw a table. In the right column, determine the growth factor.

\(x\), step number \(f(x)\), number of squares Growth factor
\(0\) \(1\) \(3\)
\(1\) \(3\) \(3\)
\(2\) \(9\) \(3\)
\(3\) \(27\) \(3\)

Step 2
Write the function to represent the pattern.

\(f(x)=3^x\)

Step 3
Determine what type of function this is.

The function is exponential.

Try It: Determining Growth Factors

Is the pattern below represented by a function that is linear, exponential, or quadratic?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to use the growth factor to determine if this pattern is represented by a linear, quadratic, or exponential function:

Step 1
Create a table and determine the growth factor.

\(x\), step number \(f(x)\), number of squares Growth factor
\(0\) \(0\)  
\(1\) \(3\)  
\(2\) \(12\) \(4\)
\(3\) \(27\) \(2.25\)

Step 2
Determine the function.

\(f(x)=3x^2\)

Step 3
Determine what type of function this is.

This is a quadratic function. The growth rate changes between each step.

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 7.4.3: Comparing Exponential and Quadratic Functions
page.contents:
Activity

Here are two functions: \(p(x)=6x^2\) and \(q(x)=3^x\).

Investigate the output of \(p\) and \(q\) for different values of \(x\). For large enough values of \(x\), one function will have a greater value than the other.

Which function will have a greater value as \(x\) increases?

Support your answer with tables, graphs, or other representations.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(q\) is larger when \(x=0\) and again when \(x=5\). Once \(x\) is larger than \(5\), \(q\) is growing much more quickly, as shown in the table.

  \(p(x)\) \(q(x)\)
\(0\) \(0\) \(1\)
\(1\) \(6\) \(3\)
\(2\) \(24\) \(9\)
\(3\) \(54\) \(27\)
\(4\) \(96\) \(81\)
\(5\) \(150\) \(243\)
\(6\) \(216\) \(729\)
\(7\) \(294\) \(2,187\)

Alternatively, here is a graph showing the plotted values from the table and another showing \(y=p(x)\) and \(y=q(x)\).



Extending Your Thinking

  1. Janna says that some exponential functions grow more slowly than the quadratic function as \(x\) increases. Do you agree with Janna? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Yes. This is true for the functions \(g(x)=(1 \frac {1}{2})x\) and \(f(x)=x^2\) as \(x\) increases for \(x\)-values less than \(10\).

  1. Could you have an exponential function \(g(x)=b^x\) so that \(g(x)<f(x)\) for all values of \(x\)?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

No, \(g(0)>f(0)\) for all values of \(b\) (except \(0\)), because \(b^0=1\) and \(0^2=0\). (If \(b=0\), there are problems if \(x\leq 0\), so this is not usually considered an exponential function.)


Video: Comparing Exponential and Quadratic Functions

Watch the following video to learn more about functions.

page.title: 7.4.3: Self Check
page.contents: Which of the following has the greatest value as \(x\) increases?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This quadratic function will increase as \(x\) increases but will not have the greatest value when compared to an exponential growth function. The answer is \(y=4^x\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: This is an exponential function with a growth factor of \(4\), which will have the greatest value as \(x\) increases.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This function is linear and has a constant difference of 4, but that will not increase as much as an exponential function. The answer is \(y=4^x\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This has a growth factor of \(\frac {1}{4}\), which will decay, not increase. The answer is \(y=4^x\).

page.title: 7.4.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Exponential versus Quadratic Functions

For each of the two functions, do the following:

  1. Complete the table of values.
  2. Sketch a graph.
  3. Decide whether each function is linear, quadratic, or exponential, and be prepared to explain how you know.
  1. \(f(x)=3\cdot 2^x\)
\(x\) \(-1\) \(0\) \(1\) \(2\) \(3\) \(5\)
\(f(x)\) \(\frac{3}{2}\) or equivalent \(3\) \(6\) \(12\) \(24\) \(96\)

This function is exponential. It has a growth factor of \(2\).

  1. \(g(x)=3\cdot x^2\)
\(x\) \(-1\) \(0\) \(1\) \(2\) \(3\) \(5\)
\(g(x)\) \(3\) \(0\) \(3\) \(12\) \(27\) \(75\)

This function is not linear because it does not have a constant rate of change, and it is not exponential because it does not have a constant growth factor. The function is quadratic because it can be represented by \(g(x)=3x^2\), which has \(x\) to the second power, and that is the greatest power.

Note: Between \(f(x)\) and \(g(x)\), \(f(x)\) will have the greater value as \(x\) increases.

Try It: Exponential versus Quadratic Functions

Which of the following has the greater value as \(x\) increases, \(f(x)\) or \(g(x)\)?

\(f(x)=3x^2\)

\(g(x)=3^x\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to determine which function has the greater value as \(x\) increases:

Make a table of values for each function, and then graph the function:

\(x\) \(-2\) \(-1\) \(0\) \(1\) \(2\) \(3\) \(4\)
\(f(x)=3x^2\) \(12\) \(3\) \(0\) \(3\) \(12\) \(27\) \(48\)

\(x\) \(-2\) \(-1\) \(0\) \(1\) \(2\) \(3\) \(4\)
\(g(x)=3^x\) \(\frac {1}{9}\) \(\frac {1}{3}\) \(1\) \(3\) \(9\) \(27\) \(81\)

Looking at both the table of values and the graphs, \(g(x)\) will have a greater value than \(f(x)\) as \(x\) increases. This is because \(g(x)\) is exponential and has a constant growth factor.

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 7.4.4: Comparing Exponential and Quadratic Expressions
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

Tyler completes the table comparing values of the expressions \(5x^2\) and \(2^x\).

\(x\) \(5x^2\) \(2^x\)
\(1\) \(5\) \(2\)
\(2\) \(20\) \(4\)
\(3\) \(45\) \(8\)
\(4\) \(80\) \(16\)

Tyler concludes that \(5x^2\) will always result in greater values than \(2^x\) for the same value of \(x\). Do you agree? Explain or show your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Tyler is not correct. For lesser values of \(x\), \(5x^2\) results in greater values than \(2^x\), but \(2^x\) eventually results in greater values because it always doubles when \(x\) increases by \(1\). When \(x=9\), \(5(9)^2=405\) and \(2^9=512\), so \(2^9\) is greater.

page.title: 7.4.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

Use the following to answer questions 1–7.

The table shows values of the expressions \(10x^2\) and \(2^x\).

\(x\) \(10x^2\) \(2^x\)
\(1\) \(10\) \(2\)
\(2\) \(40\) \(4\)
\(3\) \(90\) \(8\)
\(4\) \(160\) \(16\)
\(8\)    
\(10\)    
\(12\)    

  1. Complete the statement.

    1. When the value of \(x\) increases by \(1\), the expression \(10x^2\):

Correct! When the value of \(x\) increases by \(1\), the expression \(10x^2\) grows by increasing amounts but by decreasing growth factors.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: When the value of \(x\) increases by \(1\), the expression \(10x^2\) grows by increasing amounts but by decreasing growth factors. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. When the value of \(x\) increases by \(1\), the expression \(2^x\):

Correct! When the value of \(x\) increases by \(1\), the expression \(2^x\) changes exponentially. It doubles.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: When the value of \(x\) increases by \(1\), the expression \(2^x\) changes exponentially. It doubles. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Will the value of \(10x^2\) be greater than or less than \(2^x\) when \(x\) is \(8\)?

Correct! The value of \(10x^2\) will be greater than \(2^x\) when \(x\) is \(8\).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.4.2 and 7.4.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: The value of \(10x^2\) will be greater than \(2^x\) when \(x\) is \(8\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Will the value of \(2^x\) be greater than or less than \(10x^2\) when \(x\) is \(10\)?

Correct! The value of \(2^x\) will be greater than \(10x^2\) when \(x\) is \(10\).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.4.2 and 7.4.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: The value of \(2^x\) will be greater than \(10x^2\) when \(x\) is \(10\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Will the value of \(10x^2\) be greater than or less than \(2^x\) when \(x\) is \(12\)?

Correct! The value of \(10x^2\) will be less than \(2^x\) when \(x\) is \(12\).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.4.2 and 7.4.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: The value of \(10x^2\) will be less than \(2^x\) when \(x\) is \(12\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Determine the following values of \(10x^2\).

    1. What is the value of \(10x^2\) when \(x\) is \(8\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! When \(x=8\), the value of \(10x^2\) is \(640\).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: When \(x=8\), the value of \(10x^2\) is \(640\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. What is the value of \(10x^2\) when \(x\) is \(10\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! When \(x=10\), the value of \(10x^2\) is \(1000\).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: When \(x=10\), the value of \(10x^2\) is \(1000\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. What is the value of \(10x^2\) when \(x\) is \(12\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! When \(x=12\), the value of \(10x^2\) is \(1440\).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: When \(x=12\), the value of \(10x^2\) is \(1440\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Determine the following values of \(2^x\).

    1. What is the value of \(2^x\) when \(x\) is \(8\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! When \(x=8\), the value of \(2^x\) is \(256\).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: When \(x=8\), the value of \(2^x\) is \(256\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. What is the value of \(2^x\) when \(x\) is \(10\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! When \(x=10\), the value of \(2^x\) is \(1024\).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: When \(x=10\), the value of \(2^x\) is \(1024\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. What is the value of \(2^x\) when \(x\) is \(12\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! When \(x=12\), the value of \(2^x\) is \(4096\).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: When \(x=12\), the value of \(2^x\) is \(4096\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Choose the best statement that describes how the values of the exponential expression \(2^x\) and the quadratic expression \(10x^2\) change as \(x\) becomes greater and greater.

Correct! The value of the exponential expression grows much more quickly as \(x\) increases.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.4.2 and 7.4.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: The value of the exponential expression grows much more quickly as \(x\) increases. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Answer the following questions about functions \(f(x)\) and \(g(x)\).

    1. What type of expression is \(f(x)=1.5^x\)?

Correct! \(f(x)=1.5^x\) is an exponential expression.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 7.4.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: \(f(x)=1.5^x\) is an exponential expression. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. What type of expression is \(g(x)=500x^2+345x\)?

Correct! \(g(x)=500x^2+345x\) is a quadratic expression.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 7.4.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: \(g(x)=500x^2+345x\) is a quadratic expression. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. The values of which function will eventually be greater for larger and larger values of \(x\)?

Correct! The exponential function, \(f\), will eventually be greater for larger and larger values of \(x\).

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 7.4.2 and 7.4.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: The exponential function, \(f\), will eventually be greater for larger and larger values of \(x\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What is the value of \(x\) when the exponential expression \(3(2)^x\) eventually overtakes the quadratic expression \(3x^2+2x\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! When \(x=5\), the value of \(3(2)^x\) is greater than the value of \(3x^2+2x\).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.4.2–7.4.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: When \(x=5\), the value of \(3(2)^x\) is greater than the value of \(3x^2+2x\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The table shows the values of \(4^x\) and \(100x^2\) for some values of \(x\).
    \(x\) \(4^x\) \(100x^2\)
    \(1\) \(4\) \(100\)
    \(2\) \(16\) \(400\)
    \(3\) \(64\) \(900\)
    \(4\) \(256\) \(1,600\)
    \(5\) \(1,024\) \(2,500\)

    Looking at the patterns in the table, choose the best answer to explain why, as the value of \(x\) increases, the values of the exponential expression \(4^x\) will eventually overtake the values of the quadratic expression \(100x^2\).

Correct! The value of \(100x^2\) grows by different factors, and the value of \(4^x\) grows by a factor of 4 every time.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 7.4.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: The value of \(100x^2\) grows by different factors, and the value of \(4^x\) grows by a factor of 4 every time. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 7.4.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Explain using graphs, tables, or calculations that exponential functions eventually grow faster than quadratic functions.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 7.4.1: Comparing Expressions
    • In this activity, you compared exponential expressions and ordered them from least to greatest by reasoning about the base numbers and exponents.
  • 7.4.2: Exploring Linear, Exponential, and Quadratic Growth
    • In this activity, you examined patterns and then determined expressions that represented the patterns. You then determined if each expression was linear, exponential, or quadratic.
    • 7.4.2: Self Check
    • 7.4.2: Additional Resources
  • 7.4.3: Comparing Exponential and Quadratic Functions
    • In this activity, you compared an exponential function and a quadratic function through their tables of values and graphs. You then determined which function had a larger value as the \(x\)-values increased.
    • 7.4.3: Self Check
    • 7.4.3: Additional Resources
  • 7.4.4: Comparing Exponential and Quadratic Expressions
    • In this activity, you determined the point at which a particular exponential function is always greater than a particular quadratic function.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 7.4.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
